Fig. 1 Reaction network of propylene oxidation on a multicomponent bismuth molybdate catalyst. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 A schematic diagram of the reactor set-up capable of feed modulation between reaction/regeneration streams. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 A typical feed scheme of an FDO demonstrating modulation of propylene and oxygen, amplitude, and reaction/regeneration cycle period. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 A steady-state parametric study of the impacts of feed temperature and weight hourly space velocity on propylene conversion (a) and acrolein selectivity (b) using a 15.2 cm long bed containing 4.8 g of MMO catalyst. Feed composition: 5 % C3H6, 11.67 % O2. The weight hourly space velocity of propylene ranged from 0.12 /h to 0.40 /h, with feed temperature (measured at 2.5 cm upstream of the reactor front) adjusted between 270–355 °C. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Oxygen kinetic analysis of MMO catalyst (a) Logarithmic rate vs logarithmic partial pressure of oxygen at 330°C. Feed condition: 5 % C3H6, 5 %-14 % O2; propylene weight hourly space velocity: 0.7 /hr. (b) Apparent oxygen order as a function of temperature (T measured at 1.15 cm mark of the 2.3 cm long reactor) for propylene conversion and product formations. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Impact of temperature variation between 335 °C and 475 °C on acrolein formation and propylene conversion. The experiments were conducted using a 2.6 cm long reactor containing 0.94 g of MMO catalyst. Feed composition: 5 % C3H6, 11.67 % O2. A flow rate of 300 sccm was used in the experiments shown in a and in the four lower temperature data in b, 500 sccm in the four higher temperature data in b. (a) Integral reactor data, y axis represents the logarithmic of net rate of acrolein formation. (b) Differential reactor data, the decomposition rate of acrolein is considered essentially negligible due to low conversion of propylene. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Impact of O2/C3H6 ratio on propylene conversion (a) and acrolein selectivity (b). Experiments carried out using a 2.3 cm long bed containing 0.38 g of MMO catalyst. Space velocity was varied to keep conversion lower than 25 %. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Impact of various pretreatment schemes on a 5.2 cm long foam washcoated with 1.59 g of MMO catalyst. Feed flow rate 300 sccm for both pretreatment feed with varied O2 and full feed with 5 % C3H6 and 11.7 % O2. (a, b) Oxygen concentration varied (6–20 % O2) during 60-minute pretreatment. (c, d) Temperature was varied during 120-minute pretreatment with a 15 % O2 feed. (e, f) Four pretreatments, each consisting of 20 mmol of O2, were conducted for varying duration. First pretreatment: 15 % O2, 10 min. Second pretreatment: 7.5 % O2, 20 min. Third pretreatment: 3.75 % O2, 40 min. Fourth pretreatment: 2.5 % O2, 60 min. The pretreatment in a, b, e, and f as well as the full feed reaction in all plots were conducted with a feed temperature of 323 °C. The pretreatments and afterward full feed reactions are plotted consecutively. Reactor outlet stream was diluted 10 times with argon upstream of the FTIR. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Reactor outlet concentration profiles of acrolein (a) and propylene (b) as well as temperature profiles (a) in temperature programmed reactions (TPR) carried out in a 15.2 cm long foam washcoated with 4.8 g of MMO catalyst. Feed flow rate 300 sccm. TPRs were conducted with a feed temperature ramp of 0.5 °C/min starting at 265 °C. SS feed: 5 % C3H6, 6.67 % O2. Cyclic feed: reaction cycle: 5 % C3H6, 5 % O2; regeneration cycle: 6.67 % O2. Cycle time 10 min. Duty cycle 80 %. Reactor outlet stream was diluted 10 times with argon upstream of the FTIR. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Impact of feed temperature on product distribution in a cyclic operation on a 5.2 cm long foam washcoated with 1.59 g of MMO catalyst. Feed flow rate 300 sccm. Cyclic feed composition: 5 % C3H6 and 12 % O2 (reaction phase) alternating with 20 % O2 (regeneration phase) with a 120 min period and 50 % duty. (a–c) feed temperature 330 °C, (d–f) feed temperature 370 °C. Reactor outlet stream was diluted 10 times with argon upstream of the FTIR. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Reactor outlet concentration profiles of acrolein (a) and acrolein yield (b) as duty cycle is varied from 80 % to 50 %. Experiments were conducted with feeds at 330 °C and 300 sccm flow rate in a 5.2 cm long reactor washcoated with 1.59 g of MMO catalyst. Cyclic feed composition: 5 % C3H6 and 5 % O2 (reaction phase) alternating with 6.67 % O2 (regeneration phase) with a 10 min period. SS feed: 5 % C3H6, 6.67–11.7 % O2, oxygen concentration was adjusted to achieve the same ROR (reductant to oxidant ratio) as the cycle average ROR in the FDOs. Reactor outlet stream was diluted 10 times with argon upstream of the FTIR. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Impact of amplitude modulation of oxygen on acrolein yield. Experiments were conducted with feeds at 330 °C and 300 sccm flow rate in a 5.2 cm long reactor washcoated with 1.59 g of MMO catalyst. SS feed: 5 % C3H6, 10 % O2. Cyclic feed: 5 % C3H6, (10 ± x) % O2 with 5 min with high O2 and 5 min low O2 period. The high O2 cycles that commenced at 30 min were ongoing. With another set of experiments, the low O2 cycles beginning from 35 min were continued with low O2 concentration. Reactor outlet stream was diluted 10 times with argon upstream of the FTIR. Fig. 12 Fig. 13 Impact of cycle period. (a–i) Concentrations of acrolein, and COx with cycle period varying from 120 min to 0.5 min. Propylene conversion (g), acrolein selectivity (h), and COx selectivity (i) have been plotted against period. Experiments were conducted with feeds at 330 °C and 300 sccm flow rate in a 5.2 cm long reactor washcoated with 1.59 g of MMO catalyst. Cyclic feed composition: 5 % C3H6 and 12 % O2 (reaction phase) alternating with 20 % O2 (regeneration phase) with a 50 % duty. Reactor outlet stream was diluted 10 times with argon upstream of the FTIR. Fig. 13 Fig. 14 FDO performance of Bi2Mo3O12 catalyst (1.7 g) washcoated on a 5.2 cm long foam. Feed flow rate 300 sccm. Cyclic feed composition: 5 % C3H6 and 12 % O2 (reaction phase) alternating with 20 % O2 (regeneration phase) with a 50 % duty. Reactor outlet stream was diluted 10 times with argon upstream of the FTIR. Fig. 14 Fig. 15 Two types of reactors to separate mixing of feed reductant and oxidant. First type: reactor(s) with switching between reaction and regeneration feed (a and c). Second type: a circulating catalyst system with a reactor and a regenerator (b).
