Forced dynamic operation (FDO) of selective oxidation of propylene to acrolein is evaluated on a structured alumina foam coated with a mixed metal oxide catalyst (bismuth molybdate-based). Reactor experiments examine feed composition modulation as a strategy to increase the yield of acrolein. At lower temperatures, separating the oxidant (O2) and reductant (C3H6) enhances propylene conversion and acrolein selectivity. Variation in the reaction-regeneration switching amplitude and frequency gives a 40 % higher cycle-averaged acrolein yield compared to steady-state operation (SSO) for the same overall feed composition. The results suggest that FDO maintains a higher concentration of selective oxygen species during the propylene feed, while pre-oxidation of the catalyst maximizes the amount of selective oxygen species, leading to increased acrolein yield at the beginning of the reaction cycle. Experiments at lower temperature for both commercial promoted and in-house, unpromoted catalysts reveal both catalysts are most active and selective at their highest oxidation states. Graphical Abstract Switching between reaction and regeneration feeds during selective oxidation of propylene on bismuth-molybdate catalyst gives higher acrolein yield compared to steady state operation. Keywords Propylene Acrolein Selective oxidation Forced dynamic operation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The selective oxidation of propylene to acrolein (ACHO) is the first step in the commercial synthesis of acrylic acid (ACOOH), a key component in acrylate-based polymers [1,2]. The catalyst most commonly employed for this process is a bismuth molybdate (BiMoOx) based, mixed metal oxide (MMO) [3]. The propylene selective oxidation involves the following reactions [4,5]: R 1 : CH 2 CH CH 3 + O 2 → CH 2 CHCHO ACHO + H 2 O R 2 : CH 2 CHCHO + 0.5 O 2 → CH 2 CHCOOH ACOOH R 3 : CH 2 CH CH 3 + 2 O 2 → CH 3 CHO + C O 2 + H 2 O R 4 : CH 3 CHO + 0.5 O 2 → CH 3 COOH R 5 : CH 2 CH CH 3 + 3 O 2 → 3 CO + 3 H 2 O R 6 : CH 2 CH CH 3 + 4.5 O 2 → 3 C O 2 + 3 H 2 O R 7 : CH 2 CHCOOH + 3 O 2 → 3 C O 2 + 2 H 2 O R 8 : CH 3 CHO + 2.5 O 2 → 2 C O 2 + 2 H 2 O R 9 : CH 3 COOH + 2 O 2 → 2 C O 2 + 2 H 2 O Fig. 1 shows the reaction network structure, and Table 1 provides a list of all the chemical species and their abbreviations. The network comprises a consecutive-parallel structure in which the desired products (ACHO, ACOOH) are formed sequentially. Undesired byproducts include other oxygenates and COx (x = 1,2) Selective oxidation of propylene on (un)promoted BiMoOx catalyst is generally accepted to involve a redox cycle with the kinetics following a Mars-Van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism [1,6,7] and associated MVK rate expression. The surface redox cycle involves the sequential re-oxidation of the reduced MMO by gas phase oxygen followed by surface reduction by propylene, and other reducing species. In addition to the desired products ACHO and ACOOH, multiple byproducts including CO, CO2, acetaldehyde (AHO), acetic acid (AOOH), acetone (ACT), formaldehyde (FOR) are formed on BiMoOx catalysts [8–10]. Byproduct formation not only reduces the desired product selectivity and yield, but also introduces complications such as the polymerization of ACHO and ACOOH and fouling of the reactor [11,12]. Decreased propylene conversion and desired product (primary – ACHO; secondary – ACOOH) selectivity means increased feedstock and separation costs. The sequential oxidation and reduction steps involve mobile oxygen species that fill the MMO vacancies generated by the oxidation. Several oxygen species are known to exist on the surface or within the bulk of the BiMoOx. An unambiguous assignment of the identity and specific roles of all the reactive oxygen species remains elusive [13]. Notwithstanding this fact, Haber classified the oxygen species into two categories; lattice oxygen (O2-) and chemisorbed oxygen adspecies (O2(ad), O2 -, O-) [14–16]. Differences in propylene oxidation activity and ACHO selectivity are rooted in the identity and participation of these different oxygens. The lattice O2- is considered nucleophilic and therefore forms C-O bonds, while O2(ad), O2 - and O- are electrophilic and break C-C bonds [14–16]. ACHO forms from propylene via the intermediate allyl alcohol (ACHOH). This selective path utilizes lattice oxygen in both steps [6,7,17–21] as does the subsequent oxidation of ACHO oxidation to ACOOH. AHO is formed in parallel with ACHO from the oxidations of both propylene and ACHOH [8,22]. The C-C bond cleavage leading to AHO formation reactions involves electrophilic oxygen adspecies [9,16], as does the formation of FOR [16]. Two different FOR formation routes have been proposed; the first is from propylene dissociation to AHO and FOR [16] while a second is through ACHO oxidation [4]. Nonselective product CO is generated during the parallel oxidation of propylene while deep oxidation product CO2 forms by oxidation (combustion) of all species [4,22]. Keeping with the same classification of nucleophilic lattice and electrophilic surface oxygen species, COx formation from all hydrocarbons involves electrophilic surface oxygen [16]. The supply of oxygen consumed during the reaction may come from the gas phase or from the bulk of the oxide lattice. Under conditions when reoxidation is rate limiting the mobility of the oxygen ions is paramount. The diffusion rate depends on the defect structure of the catalyst bulk [23–25]. The activity and selectivity of unpromoted BiMoOx (α-Bi2Mo3O12, β-Bi2Mo2O9, γ-Bi2MoO6), used in the first-generation propylene to acrolein and acrylic acid process, has been improved by the addition of various metals to BiMoOx. These promoters serve to enhance the bulk oxygen mobility [19,26–28], among other roles. BiMoOx based MMOs exhibit high oxygen mobility/diffusion; as a result, the catalyst surface is efficiently replenished with selective lattice oxygen species from their bulk oxygen reservoir. Earlier work by Keulks and coworkers demonstrated that for α, β, and γ phases of BiMoOx and temperatures above 400 °C, propylene oxidation to acrolein exhibits a first order dependence on propylene and zeroth order dependence on O2. For temperatures of 300 °C and lower, the propylene order approaches 0 while the oxygen order increases towards 1 [29,30]. Similar dependencies of propylene and oxygen are reported for BiMoOx promoted by other metals [4,21,22,28,29,31,32]. The selective oxidation and byproduct formation kinetics differ. Various oxygen dependencies have been reported for the rate of formation of CO2, CO, and AHO on both unpromoted and promoted BiMoOx [4,9,21,22,29,30]. A better understanding of the propylene oxidation catalyst has been achieved through recent advances in spectroscopic measurements and mechanistic studies [20,28,33–35]. The activity and selectivity of BiMoOx catalysts has been improved through the addition of promoters (e.g., Fe, Ni, K etc.) [19,26–28]. The reaction system is conventionally carried out with a steady feed of propylene and oxygen in either fixed- or fluidized-bed catalytic reactors [36–39]. A drawback of steady-state operation (SSO) is that mixing propylene and oxygen can lead to over oxidation and selectivity losses. This has motivated consideration of feeding alternating streams containing propylene and oxygen [40,41], although this approach has not yet found commercial application primarily due to mass and heat transfer limitations in large reactors. Distributed manufacturing utilizing smaller scale reactors with forced dynamic operation (FDO) through modulation of the feed composition and/or reactor temperature may enable a higher ACHO yield. Dynamic reactor operations of catalytic reaction systems are documented in a book by Silveston et al.[42]. Key parameters that determine the impact of modulation include the apparent reaction orders, reaction network structure (parallel, consecutive, etc.), as well as reactant storage and release kinetics. Morales et al. recently demonstrated a correlation between dynamic rate enhancement and key variables in feed and reaction conditions, such as the amplitude of feed composition, phase shift, duty cycle, and the reaction order of the reactant(s) [43]. For quasi-steady state operation, modulation of reactant(s) leads to rate enhancement when the order (single reactant modulation) or sum of the orders of reactants (two reactant modulation) falls outside the 0–1 range. When the rate is convexly related to the reactant concentration, cyclic modulation of feed composition leads to an increase in the rate compared to steady state operation. Conversely, with a concave dependence, cyclic modulation leads to a decrease in the rate [42]. By frequently replenishing an industrial BiMoOx catalyst with gas phase oxygen, Gan et al. reported a substantial yield improvement for ammoxidation of propylene to acrylonitrile [44]. Similarly, Chen et al. showed that methane oxidation under lean/rich cyclic conditions over spinel supported, platinum group metal (PGM) catalysts is positively correlated with the dynamic oxygen storage capacity of the spinel phase [45]. Other examples of dynamically promoted oxidation reactions include CO oxidation [46], and partial oxidation and reforming of methane [47,48], methane oxidative coupling [49], epoxidation [50], butane oxidation to maleic anhydride [51], and complete oxidation of propylene [52]. Benefits of FDO have also been reported for dehydrogenation reactions, such as oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane [53], and propane [54]. Advantages by similar approach have also been reported for reduction reactions, such as hydrogenation of nitrogen oxides [55,56]. In this study, we systematically investigate the performance of a promoted BiMoOx commercial catalyst (provided by INEOS Nitriles USA LLC) for the selective oxidation of propylene to acrolein under temporal feed composition variation. The kinetic features of this reaction, such as the positive orders of the reactants (sum of the orders of propylene and oxygen are >1 for certain conditions) combined with the dynamic oxygen storage capacity of the catalyst render this reaction system a promising candidate for enhanced performance through periodic operation. We expect that FDO through temporal separation of feed oxygen and propylene should lead to enhanced catalyst performance in terms of propylene conversion and/or acrolein selectivity. It has been reported that decoupling the oxidation and reduction steps has the potential to improve selectivity and activity of acrolein/acrylic acid formation [40,41,57,58]. Researchers at SOHIO, the original developers of the BiMoOx catalyst for ammoxidation, also proposed a reactor concept that comprises two fluidized bed reactors – one for selective propylene oxidation and the other for re-oxidizing the reduced catalyst at a higher temperature [40]. One of the rationales behind choosing this reactor concept over a co-fed single reactor was to prevent nonselective reactions by eliminating molecular oxygen from the reactor with propylene feed. However, in the 1960s, the requirement for a large volume of catalyst circulation per unit of ACHO production on the lower active catalysts prevented the commercialization of this process. Later, advances in BiMoOx catalyst promoters enabled enhanced activity and selectivity at elevated temperatures (over 400 °C) while maintaining a single reactor configuration. Saleh-Alhamed et al. investigated the effect of feed modulation on a Sb-Sn oxide-based catalyst for a fixed bed reactor and found that propylene cycling leads to improvements in ACOOH and ACHO formation rate and selectivity [41]. With reoxidation considered rate limiting at lower temperatures [4,28,29], advanced process concepts that entail separated reduction and oxidation zones or reactors attract continued interest and study. The objective of this study is two-fold; (i) to enhance the propylene to acrolein yield under forced dynamic operation, and (ii) to elucidate the mechanism responsible for the performance enhancement. To this end, we successfully demonstrate that periodic separation of oxygen and propylene improves the yield and selectivity of acrolein and/or acrylic acid over steady state at lower temperatures (< 370 °C), where the reaction is oxidation limited. Where possible, data trends are interpreted mechanistically, guided by established findings from the literature. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The proprietary propylene ammoxidation catalyst (MMO) in powder form (notebook number 20635–9–1) was provided by INEOS Nitriles USA LLC and is identical to the one used by Gan et al. [44]. The catalyst contains a mixture of BiMoOx based metal oxides as described in several references [2,28,59–63]. For proprietary reasons the catalyst could not be analyzed further. Most of the experiments used the catalyst without modification. An unpromoted Bi2Mo3O12 catalyst was prepared by a coprecipitation method. 5.9 g ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate (AMT) (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.98 %) was dissolved in 110 ml of deionized (DI) water while 10.9 g bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (BNP) (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.98 %) was dissolved in a second 110 ml 2 M nitric acid solution (molar ratio of Bi: Mo = 2: 3). The BNP solution was slowly added to the AMT solution under continuous stirring. Then the pH of the slurry was adjusted to 3–3.5 by adding ammonium hydroxide solution. The slurry was continuously stirred and heated at 70 °C for 16 h until the solution completely evaporated. The dried material was then washed with DI water, filtered, dried again at 70 °C overnight, and ground. Finally, the powder was dried at 130 °C for 3 h and calcined at 500 °C for 6 h. Washcoated ceramic foam catalysts containing the INEOS or in-house synthesized powders were prepared as follows. A slurry was prepared by mixing 90 ml DI water and 6.6 ml 20 % boehmite solution containing 30 g of the INEOS-provided powder catalyst. A second slurry was prepared by mixing 10 g in-house synthesized Bi2Mo3O12, 8.4 ml 20 % boehmite solution and 30 ml DI water. The slurries were ball milled for 24 h and then washcoated onto the ceramic (α-Al2O3) foam substrates. This involved dipping the foams in the slurries and the excess slurry was blown off with air. Afterwards, the foams were dried in an oven at 130 °C for 2 h. The dipping procedure was repeated multiple times to obtain the desired catalyst loading. Finally, the washcoated foams were calcined at 500 °C for 5 h with a temperature ramp of 0.5 °C/min from room temperature. The ceramic foams had a pore density of either 20 or 45 pores per inch (PPI). The foams had a diameter of 2.54 cm while the length ranged from 2.3 cm to 15.2 cm. Each of the foams had a 3 mm diameter hole located at the centerline spanning the entire length. The hole enabled the insertion of three thermocouples (K type, 0.5–0.8 mm diameter) positioned at different axial points within the foam with the fourth located just upstream of the front face of the foam. Five foams containing the INEOS washcoat, and one with Bi2Mo3O12 were prepared. The dimensions and loadings of each are provided in Table S1. 2.2 Reactor setup A schematic of the reactor is shown in Fig. 2. All ultra-high purity (99.99 %) gases were supplied by Matheson Tri-gas and Praxair Inc. The feed flows were metered by a set of MKS mass flow controllers. A four-way (Valco Inc., micro-electric two position valve) was employed for feed modulation during dynamic operation. In order to avoid condensation, all gas lines were heated to 160 °C. The catalyst sample was loaded in a quartz tube (2.8 cm ID and 3.2 cm OD) which was placed in a temperature-controlled Lindberg furnace. As mentioned, several thermocouples (TCs) were used to measure the centerline foam temperature; catalyst samples 1, 5, and 6 utilized four TCs while samples 2–4 utilized three TCs. The positions of the thermocouples in the washcoat are provided in Table S2. The TC-measured temperatures were recorded using Labview™ software. The reactor effluent gas mixture was analyzed by an MKS FTIR equipped with MULTIGAS 2000 software. The reactor outlet stream was diluted 10 times with argon upstream of the FTIR unless specified otherwise. Details of the FTIR calibration are provided in the Supplemental Information (SI). 2.3 Steady-state operation: Parametric study and kinetics measurements SSO experiments were conducted to establish a baseline and probe the effects of space velocity and feed temperature. Each experiment was allotted a minimum of 30 min to reach a steady-state. All SSO experiments utilized a feed containing C3H6 and O2 diluted in Ar. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV at STP; feed propylene basis) was varied between 0.1 h−1 and 0.35 h−1, while the feed temperature was varied between 310 °C and 420 °C. The fixed C3H6 (O2) concentration of 5 % (11.7 %) corresponds to an overall lean feed mixture with reductant-to-oxidant ratio (ROR = C3H6 in/O2 in) of 0.43 (stoichiometric ROR for propylene conversion to acrolein is 1). Unless otherwise specified, this ROR was maintained during a comparison of SSO and FDO. Selected kinetic experiments were conducted to measure reaction rate orders. To estimate the oxygen rate order, the O2 feed concentration was varied from 5 % to 14 % while keeping a propylene concentration of 5 %. The propylene space velocity was adjusted to keep the propylene conversion below 25 %. 2.4 Forced dynamic operation FDO was achieved by alternating between two different compositions in the reactor, namely reaction (near stoichiometric) and regeneration (lean) feeds. FDO experiments employed a variety of reaction and regeneration feed compositions. Unless otherwise indicated, the reaction and regeneration feeds were lean, constrained by the flammability limits, shown in the SI (Fig. S10). These experiments were carried out at atmospheric pressure and over a wide range of temperatures (320–450 °C). Cycle-averaged conversion, yield, and selectivity were estimated over the final three cycles after the cyclic steady-state was achieved in each experiment. The definitions of cycle-averaged conversion ( < X > ), yield ( < Y > ), and selectivity ( < S > ) are as follows: (1) < X i > = ∫ 0 t R + G F i 0 t − F i t dt ∫ 0 t R + G F i 0 ( t ) dt (2) < Y i > = ∫ 0 t R + G Number of Carbon in i × F i t dt ∫ 0 t R + L 3 × F C 3 H 6 0 ( t ) dt (3) < S i > = ∫ 0 t R + G Number of Carbon in i × F i t dt ∫ 0 t R + G 3 × F C 3 H 6 0 t − F C 3 H 6 t dt where t R + G (s) is the time for one complete reaction (R) and regeneration (G) cycle. F i 0 (mol/s) is the feed rate of species i , and F i (mol/s) is the effluent flow rate of species i . The cycle-averaged reductant to oxidant ratio (ROR) and the duty cycle ( D ) are defined as: (4) ROR = ∫ 0 t R + G F C 3 H 6 0 ( t ) dt ∫ 0 t R + G F O 2 0 ( t ) dt (5) D = Rich period Rich period + Lean period A typical FDO feed scheme is depicted in Fig. 3. The amplitude (A) is defined as the difference between the maximum and mean feed concentrations. Except for the duty cycle modulation experiments, the periods of both half cycles are identical. Duty cycle modulations were conducted by changing the period of the half cycles while fixing the full cycle period at 10 min. The reaction phase feed contained 5.0 % C3H6 and 5.0 % O2, while the regeneration feed contained 6.7 % O2 and devoid of propylene. The cycle-averaged ROR was varied from 0.75 to 0.43 by varying the duty from 80 % to 50 %. Amplitude modulation experiments were conducted with an average ROR = 0.5 and cycle period of 10 min. In the first set of experiments, the oxygen amplitude concentration varied between 0 % and 6 %, while in the second set of experiments, the propylene amplitude varied between 0 % and 3 %. Frequency modulation experiments were conducted with feed streams of 5 % C3H6 and 12 % O2 in the reaction cycle, and 20 % O2 in the regeneration cycle. The cycle period varied between 20 s and 2 h while duty cycle was kept constant at 50 % for all the experiments. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Steady-state operation: Impact of feed temperature and space velocity A series of steady-state parametric experiments were conducted to establish a baseline for comparison of SSO with FDO and to determine the dependence of propylene conversion and acrolein selectivity on space velocity and feed temperature. Fig. 4 shows the results of experiments with feed temperatures ranging from 270 °C to 355 °C and space velocity ranging from 0.12 h−1 to 0.4 h−1. The propylene conversion dependence on feed temperature has the characteristic sigmoidal form, bounded between low (<10 %) and high (>90 %) values (Fig. 4a). There are two distinct feed temperature regimes that have different dependencies on space velocity. Above 320 °C, a space velocity increase leads to a conversion decrease, while below 320 °C, an increasing space velocity results in increasing conversion. The latter trend is a result of a nonisothermal effect, evidenced by the increasing bed temperature (at 5.1 cm mark of the 15.2 cm long reactor) with increasing space velocity. For example, at a feed temperature of 300 °C the bed temperature increases from ∼330 °C to ∼380 °C as the space velocity is increased from 0.12 h−1 to 0.4 h−1. Increased propylene flow enhances local heat generation, which increases the bed temperature due to slow heat transfer to the wall. The elevated temperatures boost the catalytic activity in the low temperature regime, which increases propylene conversion. In the high temperature regime, there is a lower temperature sensitivity of the oxidation reaction. This explains the typical conversion dependence on contact time, which is enhanced as contact time increases (i.e., space velocity decreases). In the next section, we quantify the different apparent activation energies in the two regimes. A complicating matter is the changing product distribution with feed conditions. Fig. 4b shows that the ACHO selectivity exhibits a maximum as a function of the feed temperature. With the propylene oxidation to acrolein pathway following a consecutive reaction structure, i.e., PROP → ACHO → ACOOH → CO + CO 2 , the ACHO selectivity approaches 100 % at low propylene conversion encountered at lower temperature with the parallel nonselective pathway being secondary under these conditions. As the temperature increases the consecutive reactions should become prominent as propylene conversion increases, resulting in decreasing selectivity. However, the data reveal an incomplete selectivity (<50 %) at lower temperatures. This reveals the aforementioned parallel path (as in Fig. 1). Furthermore, the gradual increase in selectivity with temperature up to the maximum suggests that the selective reaction ( PROP → ACHO ) is more temperature-sensitive compared to the parallel reactions; i.e., higher activation energy for the nonselective parallel reactions. The post-peak decrease in selectivity with temperature is attributed to the increasing significance of ACHO → ACOOH → CO + CO 2 reactions. Finally, a shorter contact time (higher space velocity) results in a higher selectivity by reducing ACHO or ACOOH residence time in the reactor. 3.2 Steady state propylene oxidation kinetics A series of kinetic experiments were conducted to measure the apparent reaction orders and activation energies. For the propylene oxidation reaction network comprising parallel and consecutive reactions (Fig. 1), the measured reaction orders necessarily involve contributions from multiple reactions. Consider the conventional formula for the apparent reaction order: (6) n j , i = d [ ln ( − r j ) ] d [ ln ( C i ) ] Here − r j is a rate of consumption (or production) of species j and C i is the concentration of reacting species i . Reaction order n j , i measures the sensitivity of a specified rate of consumption or production of species j to species i . For example, n PROP , O 2 is the apparent O2 order for propylene consumption. We emphasize that these oxygen orders observed in sequential reactions among different species are not indicative of the true reaction order. Instead, they can be referred to as apparent oxygen orders at best. That said, the magnitude of the rates and the orders provide useful information about the reaction network structure and rate limiting step(s). The impact of oxygen concentration on the rates of the various reactions, as reflected in the apparent O2 orders, provides valuable insight. Since O2 is consumed in all reactions in the propylene oxidation reaction network (Fig. 1), a host of apparent O2 orders may be determined; specifically eight apparent O2 orders using Eq. (6); i.e., n j , O 2 ( j = 1 , 8 ) . Fig. 5a shows the results for GHSV = 0.7 hr−1 and temperature of 330 °C at the mid-point (at 1.15 cm position from the front of a 2.3 cm long bed) of the bed. The rates of formation (or consumption) of each of the monitored species, excluding O2, are plotted against the partial pressure of O2. The gradient of each line corresponds to the O2 order for the formation (consumption) of each species. Similar plots at catalyst temperatures between 340 °C to 440 °C are provided in Fig. S1. At 330 °C, the O2 orders are bounded between 0.55 (AOOH) and 1.08 (CO). The orders for the main reactants and products are 0.69 (PROP), 0.75 (ACHO), 0.8 (CO2), and 1.08 (CO) at 330 °C. The nearly identical values for propylene, ACHO, and CO2 along with comparable rate magnitudes indicate that ACHO is a major product from propylene and CO2 is produced from ACHO. On the other hand, the higher value for n CO , O 2 indicates CO is formed via a different pathway than CO2. With the selective oxidation of propylene to acrolein on BiMoOx based catalysts following a redox mechanism, the acrolein production rate is limited by either reoxidation or reduction. Temperature-dependent changes in apparent O2 orders suggest a shift in the rate limiting process. Fig. 5b depicts the same set of n j , O 2 over the temperature range of 330–440 °C. The n j , O 2 for propylene, ACHO, ACOOH, and CO2 decrease with increasing temperature; generally, from values on the order of unity to values approaching 0. Thus, at lower temperature the rates of consumption/formation have a linear dependence on O2 but at much higher temperature the rates are essentially independent of O2. On the other hand, over the same temperature range the apparent O2 orders for the formations of AHO, AOOH, and FOR are relatively constant and nonzero. The O2 order for CO formation decreases as temperature increases, but is higher than the orders for ACHO, ACOOH and CO2 formation. As depicted in Fig. 1, the formation path of ACOOH proceeds through the oxidation of PROP to ACHOH, ACHOH to ACHO, and then of ACHO to ACOOH. These sequential oxidations purportedly involve lattice oxygen, and at lower temperature the reoxidation is rate determining. That this group of desired products have the same oxygen dependence suggests they are formed from the same type of oxygen. On the other hand, the formations of CO, AHO, AOOH involve C-C cleavage by unselective, electrophilic oxygen which is thought to be chemisorbed oxygen. Each of these paths has a different order with respect to O2. The constant oxygen dependency for multiple unselective products for a wide range of temperature also implies different types of oxygen other than that needed for ACHO/ACOOH formation. The apparent activation energy provides another metric for assessing reaction network structure and the rate limiting step. The apparent activation energy E j for reacting species j is as follows: (7) E j = − R d [ ln ( − r j ) ] d [ 1 / T ] E ACHO was determined over a range of temperatures between 335–475 °C as shown in Fig. 6. The conversions of propylene for experiments in Fig. 6a and b are given in the SI (Figs. S2a and S2b respectively). When the propylene conversion is below 25 %, we consider the reactor data to be differential whereas when the conversion exceeds this threshold, we treat the reactor data as integral. Fig. S2a shows that propylene conversion is greater than 25 % for the data above T > 370 °C while it is lower than 25 % for the entire temperature range in Fig. S2b. The integral reactor data, as illustrated in Fig. 6a, indicates that in the lower temperature range (T < 370 °C) gives EACHO ∼ 125 kJ/mol, whereas for T > 380 °C, EACHO ∼ 0 kJ/mol. It is not possible to conclude from the integral reactor data if a transition of ACHO formation mechanism occurs at 370–380 °C or if the increment of ACHO formation is overwhelmed by its consumption for T > 380 °C. The differential reactor data in Fig. 6b shows that EACHO is about 140 kJ/mol and EPROP is about 120 kJ/mol at temperatures below 370 °C. On the other hand, EACHO is about 51 kJ/mol and EPROP is about 55 kJ/mol at temperatures above 380 °C. Assuming ACHO consumption is negligible in the differential regime, the change in activation energy with temperature suggests a distinct transition in the ACHO formation mechanism. It is noted that the transition temperature for the differential regime is the same as for the integral regime. It is also comparable to the temperature at which the apparent O2 order for ACHO formation decreases from ∼1 to ∼0 (Fig. 5b). The difference between EACHO and EPROP at lower temperatures suggests propylene consumption occurs in parallel reactions with lower activation energy. At higher temperatures the closer agreement between EACHO and EPROP is attributed to two factors: first, the selectivity of acrolein formation increases at higher temperatures, which is discussed later in this section ( Fig. 7b); second, the activation energies of the major parallel side reactions are closer to those of acrolein formation. Finally, it is noted that the change in activation energy could also be a result of mass transfer limitations. However, we show in the SI that the mass transfer effects are negligible under the conditions we tested. Taken together, these results show that catalyst reoxidation limits acrolein formation at low temperature, while propylene oxidation, or equivalently, catalyst reduction, limits the rate at high temperatures. Krenzke et al. reported such a transition for the BiMoOx catalyst at a temperature above 400 °C [29] while Redlingshofer et al. reported a transition for promoted BiMoOx at a somewhat lower temperature of 360 °C [4]. The lower transition temperature is likely a result of the increased activity with the promoters. More recently, Amakawa et al. reported a change in mechanism with temperature for a promoted BiMoOx [28]. Such change in redox kinetics as function of temperature may suggest a Mars van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism leading to the follow rate expression: (8) r = k red k ox p PROP p O 2 n k red p R + k ox p O 2 n where k red ( k ox ) is the reduction (oxidation) rate constant. At lower temperatures (<370 °C), when the reaction is oxidation limited, r is given by r = k ox p O 2 n . At elevated temperatures (>380 °C) when the reaction is reduction limited r is given by r = k red p R . At steady state the rates of oxidation and reduction are balanced, i.e., r ox = r red . To lend further support to the switch in mechanism we examine the impact of the O2/PROP feed ratio on conversion of propylene (XPROP) and ACHO selectivity (SACHO) as shown in Fig. 7. With increased O2/PROP, XPROP increases for all the temperatures (Fig. 7a). However, the propylene conversion is more sensitive to temperature at lower temperatures (330–360 °C) compared to higher temperatures (>380 °C). This difference in the O2 dependence of the conversion in the two temperature ranges is consistent with a change of rate limiting step. The acrolein selectivity in Fig. 7b has a slight positive order dependence with O2/PROP at lower temperatures (<380 °C). Given that oxidation is limiting at lower temperatures, a higher concentration of O2 is seen advantageous. On the other hand, the acrolein selectivity has a strongly negative dependence on O2/PROP at higher temperatures (>380 °C). These results suggest that the formation of oxygenates other than ACHO (and ACHOOH) increase with O2/PROP. This trend is supported by the apparent O2 orders for oxygenates are higher than that of ACHO (Fig. 5). At elevated temperatures, the catalyst undergoes rapid oxidation; therefore, a higher O2 concentration is detrimental. 3.3 Transient operation: Impact of oxidation pretreatment To examine the impact of the degree of catalyst oxidation during FDO, we systematically varied three parameters: namely, the oxygen feed concentration, pre-oxidation duration, and feed (catalyst) temperature. Before each pretreatment the steady-state reaction with a feed containing 5 % C3H6 and 11.7 % O2 at 323 °C feed temperature was carried out to ensure an identical initial oxidation state of the catalyst. After the prescribed pretreatment, reaction under the same conditions (5 % C3H6, 11.7 % O2, 323 °C feed temperature) was carried out, and propylene and desired products acrolein (ACHO) and acrylic acid (ACOOH) were monitored as a function of time. Such a step change experiment not only provides information about the effect of oxygen pretreatment, but also provides an estimate for the time scale of surface reduction, which can be used to optimize the period of the reaction cycle. The impact of oxygen feed concentration on the effluent ACHO and propylene concentrations is shown in Fig. 8a and b. Pretreatment was carried out for 60 min at a feed temperature of 323 °C and varied O2 concentration (6–20 %). Fig. 8a shows that the O2 pretreatment, regardless of concentration, results in a notable initial boost in the ACHO production. The ACHO production is highest initially, and then decreases over ∼100 min to a constant level. The O2 feed concentration has a measurable but minor effect on the ACHO generation. The initial ACHO formation peaks are nearly identical for all four pretreatments; however, the declining ACHO regime has a nonmonotonic dependence on the O2 concentration, with the 10 % O2 giving the highest ACHO yield. Table 2 shows the amount of ACHO yield and propylene converted during one period for each of these experiments. The steady-state ACHO is independent of the pretreatment O2 level. Consistent with the ACHO yield, the propylene conversion shows a higher initial activity which declines over time and approaches a steady state value (Fig. 8b). In addition, 6 % O2 pretreatment results in slightly lower transient propylene conversions compared to the other three pretreatments. An interpretation of these findings is as follows. The prolonged pretreatment supplies the catalyst surface and subsurface with adsorbed and stored oxygen. Immediately upon its admission, the propylene reacts with the oxygen, leading to a spike in the ACHO generation, followed by a slow decrease. This trend suggests the reaction is limited by the supply of oxygen to the catalyst surface at this temperature [4,29]. Consequently, the catalyst cannot replenish its surface lattice oxygen, which is lost due to reduction. This eventually results in a lower ACHO production in an approach to steady state when rate of oxidation and rate of reduction are identical. The overall ACHO yields for a period of 120 min for each of the four pretreatments suggest that there may be an optimum O2 concentration or total amount of oxygen feed for pretreatment. The impact of pretreatment temperature is shown in Fig. 8c and d. A feed gas with 15 % O2 in Ar was conducted during 40 min of temperature-ramping from 323 °C to 345 °C or 455 °C), at which point the temperature was maintained for one hour, and then cooled to the desired reaction temperature. As before, steady state propylene oxidation was conducted at either temperature before each pretreatment. Only Ar was passed over the catalyst during the stabilization of the feed temperature at 323 °C. The full feed reaction shows that the initial spike intensity as well as the transient ACHO yield are both higher with the lower temperature pretreatment (Fig. 8b). The transient propylene conversion is also slightly higher with lower temperature pretreatment (Fig. 8e). Higher temperature pretreatment enables the oxygen to rapidly diffuse; however, lower temperatures thermodynamically favor oxygen adsorption and uptake, leading to more stored oxygen. To determine whether the O2 concentration or total amount of O2 impacts the propylene conversion or the ACHO yield, we conducted a series of experiments in which the duration and feed concentration were varied while fixing the total amount of O2 supplied during pretreatment. Fig. 8c and f show the results; included for comparison are pretreatments of the same durations but with inert Ar. The longest treatment duration (and smallest O2 concentration) gave the highest ACHO yield and propylene conversion (Fig. 8e and f). Decreasing the duration while increasing the O2 concentration resulted in a declining ACHO yield and propylene conversion. During the experiment with Ar pretreatment, there is a small, but measurable initial ACHO spike that increases slightly with pretreatment duration. This observation with Ar suggests that given the chance for prolonged equilibration, oxygen diffuses from the bulk reservoir to the reduced surface of the catalyst but this diffusion is limited at ∼ 325 °C. Thus, the key metric is the total amount of O2 stored in the catalyst and O diffusion between surface and bulk requires time for equilibration. 3.4 Steady feed operation (SFO) under temperature ramp To this point, we have established that catalyst reoxidation (reduction) is rate-limiting at low (high) temperatures, and the enhanced ACHO yield may be obtained through catalyst pre-oxidation. Furthermore, surface oxygen may be replenished by diffusion from the bulk to the surface, but the process is slow at low temperature. Next, we conduct a temperature-programmed reaction starting with a pre-oxidized catalyst and constant (time invariant) feed composition. The results are shown in Fig. 9. The catalyst was pretreated in 6.7 % O2 at a temperature of 400 °C for 1 h and then cooled to a temperature of 265 °C. A steady feed of a C3H6 (5 %) + O2 (6.7 %) was then admitted and the temperature steadily increased under a slow temperature ramp (0.5 °C /min of feed temperature). After an initial ACHO spike, as shown in Fig. 9a, there is a decreasing ACHO concentration even while the catalyst temperature (at +5 cm position) is increasing in this experiment. This counterintuitive result is a result of oxygen depletion on the catalyst surface and the rate limiting reoxidation of the catalyst combined with slow oxygen diffusion to the surface. Eventually, the ACHO concentration reaches a minimum at ca. 330 °C. Recall from earlier that the apparent activation energy in this regime is 140 kJ/mol, so, the temperature increase serves to increase the rate of oxygen supply. At the rather slow temperature ramp, the catalyst is likely approaching a pseudo steady state. The ACHO proceeds to increase until the ∼130-min mark when the temperature is ∼400 °C. As shown earlier, the ACHO selectivity decreases with temperature beyond ∼380 °C (Fig. 4b), and reoxidation is much faster. Further increase of temperature decreases ACHO selectivity due to over oxidation of ACHO to ACOOH and COx; however, PROP conversion keeps increasing. The maximum ACHO yield, being a product of the propylene conversion and ACHO selectivity, occurs at a slightly higher temperature (400 °C) than 380 °C. 3.5 Forced dynamic operation: Comparison to steady feed operation under temperature ramp We now examine the effectiveness of forced dynamic operation (FDO) on the ACHO yield (Fig. 9a) and propylene conversion (Fig. 9b). FDO is compared with steady feed operation (SFO) under an identical feed temperature ramp (0.5 °C /min rise of feed temperature beginning from 265 °C). After a pretreatment similar to SFO, a periodic feed consisting of 5 % propylene and 5 % O2 during the reaction phase and 6.7 % O2 during the regeneration phase was sustained with an 80 % duty cycle and a 10-min period. Beginning at the 0-min mark, similar to SFO, FDO exhibits an initial spike followed by a decrease in ACHO concentration. As encountered in earlier experiments, oxygen pretreatment leads to an increase in ACHO immediately upon admitting the reaction feed. At low temperatures, FDO exhibits a performance boost due to catalyst reoxidation during the regeneration phase, partially addressing the slow reoxidation kinetics encountered during SFO. However, reoxidation during the 2 min regeneration phase is apparently insufficient to fully restore the initial catalyst performance. As a result, the ACHO yield decreases even while the temperature is increasing. The ACHO concentration eventually bottoms out and proceeds to increase, reaching a peak at ∼400 °C. FDO outperforms SFO based on ACHO yield during the reaction cycle at temperatures below 370 °C; however, above this temperature the results are reversed. At higher temperatures (>400 °C) we infer from the oxygen balance that gas-phase oxygen is completely consumed during both SFO and FDO. Furthermore, the flat propylene conversion suggests that oxygen becomes the limiting reactant at these temperatures. Thus, the spikes of acrolein at higher temperatures are also a result of the replenishment of oxygen that is depleted during the reaction phase. To keep oxygen from being the limiting reactant at higher temperatures, we conducted additional SFO and FDO experiments with increased oxygen: 5 % C3H6 and 14 % O2 for SFO, with FDO using equivalent cycle-averaged ratios. The results are presented in Fig. S4. The oxygen balance indicates that gas phase oxygen is not fully utilized, even at the higher temperature of 480 °C. At lower temperatures the features of ACHO and propylene resemble those observed with lower feed oxygen (Fig. 9). The propylene conversion exhibits a continuous increase across the whole temperature range. Notably, the spike at elevated temperature is not observed during FDO, unlike the experiments conducted under conditions of oxygen as the limiting reactant (Fig. 9). 3.6 Impact of reaction temperature on transient response Having established the existence of two distinct temperature regimes, each with its own rate-determining process, it is of interest to compare the impact of FDO on each. The experiments were conducted with a reaction phase containing 5 % (12 %) propylene (O2) and the regeneration phase containing 0 % (20 %) propylene (O2). To thoroughly observe the transient response features, an extended cycle period of 2 h was chosen with 50 % duty. Fig. 10 illustrates the results of experiments conducted with feed temperatures of 330 °C and 370 °C, which results in bed temperatures that correspond to the high temperature regime where reoxidation is fast. A key issue to understand is the transient performance of the catalyst during the reaction cycle. With the low temperature feed (330 °C), the propylene conversion is maximal at the onset of the reaction phase and decreases over the entire period. Following the trend of propylene conversion, ACHO concentration also attains its maximum at the beginning. Interestingly, CO and CO2 concentrations do not exhibit their maxima simultaneously with propylene conversion; rather, they both exhibit maximum levels nearly 12 min after the reaction phase begins. Further, the selectivity ratio of ACHO to COx experiences a significant decline, dropping from 7.5 to 3.5 throughout the 60-min period. We speculate the cause to be an increase in of the fraction of unselective oxygen compared to selective oxygen during the reaction phase, as we expand on in a subsequent section. Even though propylene conversion decreases from the onset of the reaction cycle, bed temperatures do not follow that trend; rather, they follow the COx formation rate (Fig. 10c). Bed temperatures exhibit maxima at the same time as COx formation rates are at their peaks. This is attributed to the highly exothermic nature of the COx formation reactions, which primarily determine the bed temperature more so than the ACHO formation reaction. For example, heat of reaction ∆ r H 0 ( 298 K ) for acrolein formation by R1 is −380.6 kJ/mol whereas it is −1037.0 kJ/mol and −1885.9 kJ/mol CO and CO2 formation by R5 and R6, respectively [64,65]. At their peaks, bed temperatures show nearly a 20 °C rise. For the high temperature feed (370 °C), a higher propylene conversion (Fig. 10e) leads to a nearly 50 °C catalyst temperature rise (Fig. 10f) due to the exothermicity. Despite propylene conversion leveling out at the ∼75-min mark, the reactor temperature continues to increase for almost the entire reaction period; T at 2.4 cm has the highest rise and T at 4.4 cm has the lowest rise. The increase in temperature after propylene conversion has stabilized is likely due to the increase in the highly exothermic unselective reaction, as evidenced by the increase in CO2 and CO concentrations for the entire reaction phase (Fig. 10d). In contrast, the ACHO production remains essentially constant (decreases slightly, <2 % from its peak at ∼ 75-min mark). Consequently, the selectivity ratio of ACHO to COx also decreases with time (Fig. 10e), from 1.75 to 1.4 in the entire reaction period. This decline is less pronounced compared to the low temperature case. Desired product selectivity is generally expected to decline with increasing temperature, because the more activated reaction pathways to COx become accessible [4]. For this reaction network over BiMoOx catalysts it is also possible that higher temperature increases the relative amount of unselective surface oxygen compared to selective lattice oxygen. The concentration profiles of the minor products are shown in Fig. S8. The yields of these species, including AHO, AOOH, ACOOH, and FOR, decrease with time using low-temperature feed. With high-temperature feed, AHO and AOOH decrease from the onset of the reaction phase, but FOR shows a maximum yield at the ∼ 75-min mark. ACOOH continues to increase over time, which can likely be attributed to the continued temperature increase. 3.7 Forced dynamic operation: Impact of duty cycle Several FDO experiments were conducted to examine the impact of the duty cycle on the selectivity enhancement at a low feed temperature (330 °C). Fig. 11a shows ACHO yield at different FDO duty cycles and the corresponding results with SSO. The reaction mixture containing 5 % propylene and 5 % O2 was fed with four different duties (80 %, 70 %, 60 %, and 50 %) while the regeneration phase contained 6.67 % O2. The cycle period was fixed at 10 min. As discussed in the previous section, ACHO peaks at the beginning of the reaction cycle, and Fig. 11a shows that the maximum ACHO concentration increases with decreasing duty. As the duty decreases, the regeneration (reoxidation) duration increases. This leads to a more oxidized catalyst, consequently we observe two key features: a higher initial ACHO peak and a steeper downward slope following the peak. These observations reflect the oxygen storage and consumption in regeneration and reaction phase, respectively. The ACHO yield from each FDO experiment exceeds the yield from the corresponding SSO experiment. However, the percentage improvement of the ACHO yield is highest (40 %) at 80 % duty, decreasing to ∼10 % improvement at 50 % duty (Fig. 11b). The decrease in ROR that occurs with decreasing duty indicates that higher oxygen levels are advantageous for ACHO yield, as encountered during FDO and SSO. The improvement in the ACHO yield is due to both an increase in propylene conversion and ACHO selectivity (Fig. S5) which are consistent with the lower temperature operation (Fig. 7). The higher catalyst oxidation state facilitates the maintenance of elevated levels of selective oxygen. We elaborate on this aspect in a subsequent section. 3.8 Forced dynamic operation: Impact of amplitude Amplitude modulation experiments were carried out with a baseline feed of 5 % C3H6 and 10 % O2, corresponding to ROR = 0.5. We examined the amplitude of both oxygen and propylene, by altering the concentration of one gas while maintaining the other fixed. Since oxygen and propylene amplitude variations led to similar conclusions, we summarize the propylene results in the SI and provide details on the oxygen amplitude experiments here. Three discrete oxygen amplitude experiments were conducted with A = ± 2, ± 4, and ± 6 %. Experimental conditions for these experiments are listed in Table 3. Steady-state data with various O2 feed concentrations are included for comparison. The impact of oxygen amplitude is shown in Fig. 12. The experiments begin with a high O2 cycle at 0 min. Three complete cycles were executed, each comprising a 5-min high O2 phase followed by a 5-minlow O2 phase. At the 30-min mark, a final high O2 phase for all three amplitude modulations began and were extended to approach steady state. Additionally, three separate experiments were conducted with identical conditions. In these cases, after three and one-half full cycles, the low O2 phases commencing at the 35-min mark were extended to enable an approach to steady states. The data from these extended low O2 cycles are presented in the box within Fig. 12. We first discuss the extended high O2 and low O2 phases, along with the baseline. The SSO data, achieved near the end of the extended experiments, reveal a positive dependence between O2 concentration and the formation of ACHO. Notably, the increase in ACHO formation is more pronounced when the O2 concentration increases from 12 % to 14 % compared to the increase observed from 4 % to 6 %. At first glance, these findings appear inconsistent with propylene oxidation governed by the MVK mechanism (Eq. (8)), as under isothermal conditions Eq. 8 dictates that the rate of reaction should be more sensitive to oxygen at lower O2 concentration. However, the higher activity due to the increase of O2 concentration leads to elevated temperature in the bed due to the reaction system exothermicity. We observed a mid-bed temperature increase from 342 °C to 355 °C as the O2 feed concentration was increased from 4 % to 16 %. This temperature rise further speeds up the reaction rate, compounding the impact of increased O2. Next, we focus on the cyclic response observed over a complete cycle. For each amplitude modulation, the ACHO yield increases during the high O2 regeneration phase and decreases at a similar rate during the low O2 reaction phase. The change in rate with time, which is represented by the slope in high O2/low O2 cycle, is positively correlated with the amplitude. Higher amplitude results in steeper slopes because in such cases, there is a larger difference in O2 concentration between low O2 and high O2 phases. At the end of the high O2 phase, the ACHO concentration converges to nearly identical values for all three amplitudes. In contrast, the reaction phase endpoints show notable differences, where larger amplitudes lead to significantly lower ACHO concentrations. This cyclic response demonstrates a higher O2 sensitivity at lower O2 concentration, consistent with the MVK mechanism under isothermal conditions. The bed temperature variation in low O2 and high O2 cycle is less significant compared to the corresponding SSO, hence, isothermal conditions are more closely approached. For example, during the ± 6 % modulation, the mid-bed temperature varies between 348 °C and 352 °C during the reaction and regeneration phases. Overall, for conditions shown in Fig. 12 larger amplitudes lower the cycle-averaged ACHO yield. Only near the end of the high O2 feed does the ACHO yield exceed the SSO value. The lower cycle-averaged yield can be attributed to the observation that the low O2 cycle quickly reaches low activity, whereas the high O2 cycle only slowly recovers high activity. The slow recovery is consistent with the slow reoxidation observed in Fig. 8e. We note that the observations from our amplitude study in Fig. 12 are specific to the choice of overall lean cycle conditions at ROR = 0.5, where only the oxygen concentration is varied and both phases contain mixtures of propylene and oxygen. According to Vempatti et al. dynamic enhancements may only be expected if the two endpoints of the oscillation fall into distinct kinetic regimes [66]. Indeed, in other FDO schemes we used regeneration cycles without any propylene and reaction cycles with stoichiometric composition (ROR = 1) and show some of the highest observed yields in Fig. 11. In the net lean regime, the advantage of the higher O2 concentration during the high O2 cycle is lost during the low O2 part of the cycle. The positive order in O2 dictates the slower ACHO formation during the low O2 phase compared to the high O2 phase. We further speculate that some of the reduced sites do not get oxidized with propylene contained in the feed as those sites might be blocked by accumulating carbonaceous species. Burban et al. showed that during the oxidative dehydrogenation of 1-butene to 1,3-butadiene at temperatures lower than 400 °C, the BiMoOx was poisoned by product butadiene [67]. Applied to propylene oxidation, this would suggest that complete separation of propylene and oxygen is required during the high O2 cycle to attain a sufficient oxidation state, or accumulated/stored oxygen, so as to supply oxygen long enough during the low O2 feed for the instantaneous FDO yield to exceed the SSO yield. This is supported by our observations in Figs. 8 and 9. Similar to the oxygen amplitude variation, the propylene amplitude was varied while keeping the O2 feed concentration constant. The impact of propylene amplitude is shown in Fig. S6. The transient behavior is qualitatively similar to oxygen amplitude variation experiments, and the cycle-averaged ACHO yield does not exceed that of SSO in any of these experiments. Following Morales et al., consider modulation of A for the simple A → B reaction. Assuming quasi-steady state (QSS) operation, modulation will have negative impact on reaction rate when the reaction order is the 0 – 1 range [42,43]. We observed for the BiMoOx catalyst that 0 < n O 2 < 1 and the propylene order is reported in the range 0 < n PROP < 1 [4,29]. As a result, feed composition modulation of one of the two feed components for propylene oxidation should not result in enhanced ACHO formation. On the other hand, simultaneous modulation of two feed components is expected to increase the reaction rate when the sum of the orders of these species falls out of 0–1 range [43]. Our observations for simultaneous modulation of O2 and propylene show improved conversion and yield suggesting that the sum of orders of O2 and propylene is greater than unity (given that none of them are negative). 3.9 Forced dynamic operation: Impact of cycle time Given that the rates of surface reduction and reoxidation are most pronounced immediately after transitioning from a regeneration-to-reaction and reaction-to-regeneration environment, respectively, we expect that higher frequencies (or shorter periods) are beneficial for ACHO yield. Fig. 13 shows stabilized cycles at cycle times between 120 min and 30 s for a feed with 50 % duty cycle. The reaction and regeneration propylene (O2) is 5 % (12 %) and 0 % (20 %), respectively, corresponding to cycle-averaged ROR of 0.16. The decision to use a lower cycle-averaged ROR in this experiment, as opposed to previous tests, is based on the need to increase O2 for higher activity in a practical fashion by reoxidizing in the regeneration cycle using air (20 % O2) while keeping the ROR during the reaction cycle above the flammability limit (Fig. S10 in the Supplemental Information provides a flammability map wherein key feed compositions studied are identified.). The feed temperature is 330 °C, within the regime of oxidation control. The temporal profiles are shown for PROP, ACHO, CO, and CO2. For cycle times of 4 min and longer (Fig. 13a to c), the instantaneous PROP conversion (inverse of concentration) and ACHO yield (concentration) are highest during the early part of the reaction cycle, declining gradually towards steady state levels but interrupted by the switch to regeneration feed. The longest cycle time, 120 min, shows the characteristic ACHO peak (Fig. 13a). The CO and CO2 concentrations exhibit shallow maxima, indicating that the ACHO selectivity is highest early in the reaction part of the cycle. Overall, a decreasing cycle period leads to a monotonically increasing propylene conversion (Fig. 13g) and ACHO selectivity (Fig. 13h), and initially decreasing (120–4 min) then flattening (4–0.5 min) COx selectivity (Fig. 13i). Thus, the results confirm our expectation that faster cycling improves propylene conversion and ACHO selectivity. However, with the faster cycling (1-min and 0.5-min cycle times) propylene and acrolein are observed not just during the reaction feed but also during the regeneration feed (see Figs. 13e and 12f). This suggests some degree of mixing of the two feed streams upstream and within the reactor. This was corroborated by a non-reaction experiment carried out at room temperature (Fig. S7). In the limit of a very short cycle time in the order of seconds the feed will become mixed to the point that the operation approaches SSO. A summary of the impacts of several the dynamic parameters is provided in Table 4. 3.10 Mechanistic considerations In this section we interpret the data trends, underpinned by the established understanding of mechanistic aspects of the selective oxidation of propylene. Without accompanying in situ surface measurements such as DRIFTS, Raman, or XANES, and not knowing the specific identities and amounts of promoters, we rely on previous literature. We also provide some data for unpromoted BiMoOx catalyst to emphasize certain points. As introduced earlier, oxygen species classified as nucleophilic (selective, lattice) and electrophilic (unselective, surface) participate in the chemistry. During FDO, the relative amounts of these species vary with time. Consider the sequence of steps during oxidation on an unpromoted BiMoOx catalyst. During reaction with propylene, following Getsoian et al.[20], lattice oxygen (O2-) is oxidized to O in R10, generating electrons, which leads to the reduction of Mo 6 + to Mo 5 + in R11. Mo 5 + can undergo further reduction to Mo 4 + in R12, and this deep reduced form can be identified in the reduced catalyst [68]. R 10 : O 2 − ⇌ O + 2 e − R 11 : e − + Mo 6 + ⇌ Mo 5 + R 12 : e − + M o 5 + ⇌ Mo 4 + Lattice and gas phase oxygen may oxidize the reduced Mo sites. For simplicity we further discuss the oxidation of Mo 5 + . Dioxygen activates on reduced site following steps R13–17, generating several oxygen species ( O 2 ( ad ) , O , O 2 − , O − , O 2 − ) following steps in R13–18 [69]. R 13 : O 2 ( g ) ⇌ O 2 ( ad ) R 14 : O 2 ad + Mo 5 + ⇌ O 2 − + Mo 6 + R 15 : O 2 ( ad ) ⇌ 2 O R 16 : O + Mo 5 + ⇌ O − + Mo 6 + R 17 : O 2 − + Mo 5 + ⇌ 2 O − + Mo 6 + R 18 : O − + Mo 5 + ⇌ O 2 − + Mo 6 + The various oxygen species present in this system are classified into two categories: electrophilic ( O 2 ( ad ) , O , O 2 − , O − ) and nucleophilic ( O 2 − ) [14,70]. Electrophilic species are suggested to be responsible for the attack on unsaturated carbon and deep oxidation [14,71]. It is widely accepted that lattice oxygen, O 2 − , reacts with propylene to form acrolein following R19. R 19 : C 3 H 6 + 2 O 2 − ⇌ C 3 H 4 O + H 2 O + 4 e − However, O 2 − can end up in acrolein through O − , following reverse reaction of R18 [20,35,69]. Thus, during FDO the oxidation state of the molybdenum cation shuttles between + 6 and + 4 for BiMoOx while O 2 − coordinated with Mo 6 + serves as the selective oxygen. Molecular O 2 in its triplet ground state acts as an electron acceptor. Therefore, O 2 ( g ) adsorbs more strongly on a reduced surface, shifting the equilibrium of R13 to the right. Moreover, we anticipate the equilibriums of R14, R16–17 are shifted to the right, hence, only the presence of Mo 5 + transforms/creates the electrophilic oxygen species in these steps. Simply put, the more reduced surface generates more electrophilic oxygen species during dioxygen activation. It should be noted that the selective lattice oxygen is a terminal, double bonded O atom to Mo (MoO) [20]. But it is the O atom that points towards the lone pair electrons of a nearby Bi atom. While the Bi atom itself does not change oxidation state, it electronically stabilizes the transition state. It is truly “just a promoter” and not directly involved in any bond making/breaking step. Commercial catalysts, such as the INEOS-supplied ammoxidation sample provided for the current study, contain at least 3 dopants leading to a multicomponent BiMoOx catalyst with a general formula M2+M3+M1+BiMoOx (M2+ = Co, Ni; M3+ = Fe, Cr, Al; M1+ = K, Na). Amakawa et al. provided a detailed structural and mechanistic insights of Bi-Mo-Co-Fe-K-O commercial catalyst [28]. The BiMoOx ensembles supported on β-Co1-xFexMoO4 perform propene oxidation and the β-FeMoO4/Fe2Mo3O12 phases pool electrons and activate dioxygen. K doping facilitates charge transfer between two active sites and masks one type of surface acid site that gives complete oxidation. The presence of a minor phase of α-Bi2Mo3O12 may help to regenerate surface BiMoOx ensembles as in the long run Mo sublimates from the surface. In doped BiMoOx catalyst, the formation of electrophilic and nucleophilic oxygen species involves metal ions (dopants) with more facile redox properties. The addition of dopants is thought to improve the redox efficiency of the catalyst by activating gas phase oxygen and promoting the diffusion of lattice oxygen to the propylene activation site, increasing the supply of selective oxygen. For Fe-doped BiMoOx, Fe exists as both Fe 3 + and Fe 2 + . Reduction of Fe 3 + to Fe 2 + is more labile than that of Mo 6 + to Mo 5 + . However, Fe requires pairing with a M2+ promoter (such as Co/Ni) to improve the catalyst activity [72]. The M2+ promoter participates in the Co(/Ni)MoO4 phase that stabilizes Fe 2 + within the FeMoO4 ensemble, which serves as the active site for oxygen activation [28]. However, there needs to be a balance between Fe 2 + and Fe 3 + for efficient transport of electrons from the propylene activation site to oxygen activation site [28]. The ratio of bulk nucleophilic and surface electrophilic oxygen, R NE , is defined as (9) R NE = nucleophilic oxygen electrophilic oxygen = C O 2 − C O 2 ads + C O 2 − + C O - Under oxidation limited conditions, the catalyst is partially reduced. Electrophilic oxygen species are formed on the partly reduced sites ( Mo 5 + or Mo 4 + ) in R13–17. Moreover, nucleophilic O 2 − can convert to electrophilic O − via reverse reaction in R18. As a result, periodic reoxidation of the catalyst is essential to keep R NE elevated by keeping Mo in its highest oxidation state ( Mo 6 + ), which results in a higher selectivity to ACHO. The low temperature FDO data from this study suggest that R NE is highest at the end of the regeneration half cycle. During the ensuing reaction cycle R NE decreases since the supply of surface lattice oxygen must come from gas phase and subsurface oxygen diffusion. However, at lower temperature both oxygen supply processes are activated and may be too slow to keep up. As a result, Mo 6 + sites are reduced to Mo 5 + and Mo 4 + via reactions R11 and R12 for unpromoted BiMoOx. The addition of dopants enhances oxidation of the reduced Mo sites. The more oxidized catalyst favors the formation of ACHO as main product and ACOOH as minor product, because both products require access to nucleophilic lattice O2-. As the relative amounts of reduced cations increase, and therefore, electrophilic oxygen species increases, the selectivity towards COx increases [73]. AHO is derived from both PROP and ACHOH (Fig. 1). With a decrease in R NE , the concentration of ACHOH likely declines (we did not measure this species), the concentration of AHO also lowers as ACHOH to AHO rate is more dominant than PROP to AHO rate [22]. AOOH is formed by oxidizing AHO, therefore, decreasing AHO also decreases AOOH. ACOOH and FOR forms from ACHO. Thus, a decrease in ACHO decreases formation of these species. At elevated temperature (>370 °C), the selectivity of these species does not change significantly with time, which suggests that R NE remains constant. Reduced Mo sites are more efficiently oxidized by both gas phase oxygen and subsurface oxygen. However, this does not guarantee there are no reduced metal sites and associated electrophilic oxygen. 3.11 Performance of unpromoted Bi2Mo3O12 catalyst To provide additional insight into the mechanism, we conducted a limited number of propylene oxidation experiments and compared the dynamic behavior of the unpromoted Bi2Mo3O12 catalyst and the commercial INEOS BiMoOx. The results for identical feed composition and FDO variables as those used in temperature impact studies on the INEOS catalyst are presented in Fig. 14. Isothermal conditions can be presumed because of the low propylene conversion (< 10 %) at 340 °C obtained with the unpromoted Bi2Mo3O12 (Fig. 14c). Fig. 14a shows that the production of main products, including ACHO, CO, and CO2, experiences an initial surge at the introduction of the reaction feed. However, their rates of formation diminish as time progresses. A similar declining trend is observed for other byproducts (Fig. S9). Throughout the 1-h reaction period, propylene conversion experiences a significant drop, decreasing from 8 % to 4 % (Fig. 14b). In addition, the selectivity ratio of ACHO to COx decreases from 1.4 to 0.9 during the same period. A similar trend is observed with INEOS BiMoOx with the selectivity ratio decreasing from 7.5 to 3.5 (Fig. 10). Both catalysts are clearly more selective for ACHO at the start of the reaction phase. Following earlier discussion, at 340 °C the redox reaction is oxidation-limited. As such, the prolonged exposure to the reaction feed should lead to a gradual decrease in the catalyst oxidation state. Thus, both catalysts are most selective when the oxidation state is highest. This is consistent with the mechanistic considerations discussed in the previous section. 3.12 Reactor considerations We have shown that FDO of propylene selective oxidation enables enhanced catalyst performance in the oxidation-limited regime existing at lower temperatures. Periodic switching between regeneration and reaction feeds helps to maintain a higher acrolein selectivity and propylene conversion. The mechanistic interpretation is that the catalyst has a larger supply of selective oxygen (O2-). However, feed composition modulation complicates the reactor system design operation. Two reactor design options may be considered to accommodate the feed modulation ( Fig. 15). The first involves feed switching to multiple fixed beds (Fig. 15a and c) while the second involves circulation of catalyst between a net oxidizing (reoxidation) and net reducing reactors (Fig. 15b); i.e., propylene and O2 segregation is temporal in the former and spatial in the latter. Both of these approaches provide for a more flexible feed composition to improve performance while meeting safety constraints compared to steady feed operation. However, each approach has its own challenges. The fixed bed configuration with its temporal variability requires multiple catalyst beds to achieve a steady product flow, while the fluidized catalyst approach requires close attention to attrition resistance. In the oxidation-limited regime, the catalytic activity and selectivity can be improved at steady-state by increasing the supply of O2, as was shown in Fig. 7 and S5. However, the SSO catalyst performance is inferior to that under FDO. Another consideration is the allowable feed composition due to flammability. Refer to the flammability map in Fig. S10. A flammable mixture may be avoided for any propylene concentration if the O is below ∼ 12 %. That is, a minimum ROR is required. For example, for a 5 % propylene feed, the ROR should exceed 0.35. On the other hand, separation of propylene and oxygen during FDO allows for the use of cycle-averaged feed compositions that would be flammable under SSO. Fig. S10 includes the feed concentrations considered in this study. Periodically switching the feed to a single catalyst bed is clearly a disadvantage as there will be periodic start and stop of the product flow. The temporal composition variation in the reactor outlet will complicate downstream processing, which can be avoided by using a hold up vessel. As an alternative to storage, employing a minimum of two reactors, one for hydrocarbon oxidation (catalyst reduction) and another for catalyst regeneration (reoxidation) [40]. Depending on how fast a reduced catalyst bed can be re-oxidized and to what extent, both the number of reactors fed with reaction and regeneration phase will vary. Another disadvantage of feed modulation is that if the reactor outlet stream cannot be synchronously switched with feed switching, which is difficult to achieve, a common outlet from all the reactors will have lower product concentrations due to off gas from the reoxidation unit, complicating the downstream separation. The fluidized bed circulating catalyst approach, also known as chemical looping [74], may avoid the abovementioned limitations of feed modulation. In this system, catalyst reduction and reoxidation are accomplished in separate units by moving the catalyst between units [57], allowing continuous product flow and separated streams for the products and off gas from the regeneration unit. The cost of circulating the catalyst may be prohibitive, especially when a large catalyst circulation rate is needed. Moreover, the attrition and loss of catalysts during transport is another disadvantage of this type of reactor. Finally, it should be mentioned that the feed segregation may be achieved in a membrane reactor. Two types of membranes can be used. In one case, the membrane acts as a passive oxygen distributor, channeling molecular oxygen (O2) to the catalyst it supports [75]. Alternatively, the membrane can be an active material providing oxide ions (O2-) at the surface and conducting them through its structure [76,77]. However, membrane reactors face other challenges such as stability of the membrane material and the efficiency of oxidant transport. The choice of reactor depends on the techno-economic analysis of the abovementioned various reactor systems, which is beyond the scope of this paper. We have attempted to optimize the feed modulation in FDO with the studies of pretreatment, duty cycle, and cycle period. For FDO, during the regeneration phase of a reactor, the reaction feed can be fed to another reactor. An optimal number of reactors can be used to sustainably process both reaction and regeneration feed (Fig. 15c). The duty cycle variation (Fig. 10) demonstrates that the FDO is most advantageous when the duty cycle is in the range of 50–80 %. For example, a reactor system with 80 % duty cycle can be configured with four reactors fed with the reaction feed and one reactor fed the regeneration feed. Each reactor is periodically re-oxidized by the regeneration stream. A second FDO parameter that must be tuned is the cycle period. Based on the results shown in Fig. 12, it is clear that reducing the period has a positive impact on both propylene conversion and ACHO selectivity. However, further reducing the period below a 2-min cycle results in a mixing effect for a 50 % duty cycle. At an 80 % duty, as the reoxidation period gets narrower, the mixing effect will be even more pronounced. The data suggest running the reactor with a 4-min period will give optimal results. At elevated temperatures (T > 370 °C) the feed switching strategy of FDO did not result in ACHO yield improvements. However, there are still potential benefits when separating propylene and oxygen in the feed. The lower oxygen order of ACHO formation compared to other byproduct formation, particularly at higher temperatures (Fig. 5b), suggests the use of the membrane reactor with a distributed oxygen feed to improve ACHO selectivity. The detrimental effect of O2/PROP on the ACHO selectivity (Fig. 7b) also supports this reactor model. 4 Conclusions A systematic study varying feed temperature and space velocity was conducted to establish the steady-state performance of an industry-standard, promoted bismuth molybdate (BiMoOx) catalyst for the selective oxidation of propylene (PROP) to acrolein (ACHO). The apparent oxygen kinetics under steady-state conditions implicate oxidation of the catalyst surface as rate limiting below 370 °C, while at higher temperatures, the reduction of the catalyst is rate limiting. The catalyst shows maximum selectivity to ACHO at a moderate temperature because of ACHO being an intermediate species in a set of series reactions. We also investigated preconditioning the catalyst with gas phase O2. At lower temperatures, preconditioning the catalyst with oxygen results in a noticeable increase in ACHO. An examination of systematic reoxidation shows that the ACHO yield increases more when the reoxidation process lasts longer at a lower temperature. The combination of lower temperature and longer duration improves the thermodynamics and accommodates the slow kinetics of oxygen storage, respectively. By introducing frequent regeneration cycles with excess oxygen, we demonstrate increased selectivity and yield to ACHO compared to steady-state operation. The extent of yield enhancement achieved through forced dynamic operation (FDO) is greatly influenced by temperature, with lower temperatures (T < 370 °C) giving more favorable results. Catalyst reoxidation by FDO is key to improve ACHO production and selectivity in a temperature regime where oxidation is slow. At elevated temperatures, oxidation is not kinetically relevant, and frequent reoxidation by FDO does not offer any catalytic improvements. A systematic analysis of dynamic characteristics such as duty cycle, amplitude, and frequency were carried out to examine their influence on catalyst performance. An improvement of up to 40 % in ACHO yield is achieved when using FDO at an 80 % duty cycle compared to steady feed operation. Reducing the duty cycle enhances yield; however, the difference in yield between FDO and SSO declines as the duty cycle decreases. An examination of oxygen amplitude indicates the necessity of intermittently isolating oxygen from propylene in the feed. Frequency variations indicate that the ACHO production rises as the cycle time drops from 2 h to 20 s. For cycles lasting less than 60 s, the mixing impact between the two cycles is strong, preventing the process from operating beyond the flammable range. Our findings can be rationalized with a mechanism that implicates nucleophilic lattice oxygen (O2-) as the source of selective oxygen, whereas electrophilic surface oxygen (O2(ad), O-, O2 -, O) favors unselective pathways to COx. While performance trends obtained for an in-house synthesized, unpromoted Bi2Mo3O12 catalyst by and large reflect the observations on the commercial BiMoOx catalyst, the presence of various promoters increases the oxygen storage properties and maintains a higher surface oxidation state, which benefits the performance under both steady-state and FDO conditions. Overall, this study demonstrates that optimization of propylene oxidation to acrolein at lower temperatures can be achieved by FDO. To leverage FDO benefits under economic and safety considerations, we suggest a multibed reactor system. The FDO systems described here may be advantageous for various other selective oxidation and dehydrogenation processes in which the catalyst oxidation is kinetically relevant. coredata.dc:description: Forced dynamic operation (FDO) of selective oxidation of propylene to acrolein is evaluated on a structured alumina foam coated with a mixed metal oxide catalyst (bismuth molybdate-based). Reactor experiments examine feed composition modulation as a strategy to increase the yield of acrolein. At lower temperatures, separating the oxidant (O2) and reductant (C3H6) enhances propylene conversion and acrolein selectivity. Variation in the reaction-regeneration switching amplitude and frequency gives a 40 % higher cycle-averaged acrolein yield compared to steady-state operation (SSO) for the same overall feed composition. The results suggest that FDO maintains a higher concentration of selective oxygen species during the propylene feed, while pre-oxidation of the catalyst maximizes the amount of selective oxygen species, leading to increased acrolein yield at the beginning of the reaction cycle. Experiments at lower temperature for both commercial promoted and in-house, unpromoted catalysts reveal both catalysts are most active and selective at their highest oxidation states.
